CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 3;Preliminary objection rejected (incompatibility ratione materiae);Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the applicant reported to the police station ( gendarmerie ) at FAC , in LOC , to be questioned in connection with a complaint lodged by a contractor , PERSON , the applicant 's former employer , who suspected him of having sabotaged his CARDINAL bulldozers .

CARDINAL . At TIME the applicant was taken into police custody . According to the report drawn up by Mr PERSON , the police officer in charge of the investigation , the applicant ran off after learning that his wife had told the police officers that he sometimes got up during TIME . He was caught QUANTITY further on and was taken , struggling , back to the police station . There he offered further resistance , kicking out . He was restrained with the assistance of the brigade commander , PERSON .
CARDINAL . At TIME the applicant was examined by PERSON , who , after taking his blood pressure and carrying out a cardiovascular examination and an auscultation of the lungs , found nothing amiss .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was questioned again from TIME and denied having committed the offence . However , he did not dispute that he had run away from the police station and had resisted the police officers who were attempting to arrest him . According to the record of the interview , which took place at TIME , the applicant stated :

“ At TIME , when I came to the police station following your request , you told me that you suspected me of having sabotaged PERSON 's bulldozers ... You said that my wife had told you that I sometimes got up during TIME , and that is when I ran off . You managed to catch me QUANTITY further on ; I struggled to break free , but I had no intention of getting away . When you took me to the station , I again put up a struggle because I did n't want to go to prison . It is true that I tried to get away , but if I had managed to escape , I would have come back . I stamped my feet when you held me on the LOC , and if I kicked any of you , it was unintentionally . ... When I tried to run away , it was to see my wife and get her to come to the police station so that she could tell you in front of me whether I went out at TIME . ... ”

CARDINAL . At TIME , because there was substantial , consistent evidence to justify charging him with forceful resistance to a public officer , the applicant was placed in a security cell , where he remained until TIME the following morning ( DATE ) . When questioned again by the senior police officer ( officier de police judiciaire ) , he admitted having caused the damage and signed a statement to that effect at TIME He was allowed a rest from TIME At TIME he was questioned once again and confirmed his previous confessions , adding that he was sorry that he had “ jostled ” the police officers while attempting to escape .

CARDINAL . At TIME , after signing the record of his detention in police custody and his last statement , which , like the earlier ones , had been read aloud to him because he had stated that he could not read or write NORP very well , the applicant was released .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE after being released from custody , the applicant was examined by PERSON . The medical certificate drawn up by the doctor stated : “ [ The applicant ] has heavy bruising on the right anterior deltoid , with impaired mobility of the right shoulder . There are also signs that both wrists have been bound , causing pain and reduced mobility . CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint against the Le Lorrain police with the Fort - de - GPE public prosecutor , alleging assault occasioning actual bodily harm and relying on the certificate issued on CARDINAL DATE .

“ On DATE ] ... I was received [ at the police station ] at CARDINAL p.m. , and before I had even sat down , the police officer ... started reading out a list of questions . CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a further complaint with the senior investigating judge , alleging assault occasioning actual bodily harm and applying this time to join the proceedings as a civil party . The complaint referred by name to police officers PERSON , PERSON and PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE , having regard to the applicant 's complaint against the police officers and pursuant to LAW , the FAC GPE public prosecutor applied to ORG to designate the court to be responsible for the investigation or trial of the case .

CARDINAL . CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG , in the presence of PERSON and PERSON , interviewed PERSON . The following is an extract from the interview :

“ Question ... : It appears from the medical certificate issued by PERSON that on DATE ... CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( since repealed ) provides :

“ Where a senior law - enforcement officer [ officier de police judiciaire ] is likely to be charged with a criminal offence , allegedly committed in the area in which he performs his duties , whether or not in the course of those duties , ... , the public prosecutor dealing with the case shall without delay submit an application to ORG , which shall proceed and determine the matter in accordance with the procedure for settling conflicts of jurisdiction and shall designate the court responsible for the investigation or trial of the case . ”

CARDINAL . It is clear from previous cases that the procedure laid down in Article CARDINAL , which was in force at the material time , must be set in motion without delay by the public prosecutor – regardless of whether the proceedings were instituted by the prosecution or by the complainant – as soon as the senior law - enforcement officer is accused and therefore likely to be charged . Otherwise , the investigating judge and , consequently , ORG have no jurisdiction ORG , DATE , Bulletin criminel no . CARDINAL ; DATE , ibid . , no . CARDINAL ; Full court , LAW DATE , ibid . , no . CARDINAL ) .

In addition , a senior law - enforcement officer named in a complaint as the perpetrator of an offence must be regarded as likely to be charged within the meaning of Article CARDINAL ; it is not necessary to find that there is sufficient evidence to warrant the charge .

Lastly , the procedure laid down in LAW must be set in motion by the public prosecutor , regardless of whether proceedings were instituted by means of direct committal or on a complaint lodged with a civil - party application ( ORG , DATE , D. DATE , CARDINAL , note by ORG ) .
